awd_titl_txt: RoL: RAISE: DESYN-C3: A platform for Modular Pseudo-Organelles for Compartmentalization and Control of Pseudo-Cell Processes
awd_abstract_narration:
Manufacturers culture cells to produce vaccines and protein-based drugs. These products are complex and difficult to synthesize because they are composed of proteins. Growing cells is not very efficient for production because a cell uses a lot of energy and raw material to grow and maintain itself in addition to making a particular product. This limitation spurs an interest in creating synthetic cells to mimic the cellular processes that support product formation rather than cell growth. Some cellular processes occur in separate compartments to avoid interference with each other. This project will attempt to create synthetic compartments where biological reactions can take place. Success would make creating complex molecules and proteins easier. It would also increase our understanding of how cells perform and coordinate critical functions. The project results will be shared with the general public through videos. Lab tours will be provided to girls through the Career Day for Girls program at Northwestern. Underrepresented minority students from Chicago Public Schools will also be mentored. These efforts should encourage more students to pursue careers in STEM-related fields.

Controlling when and where biomolecular reactions take place remains a significant challenge in the design of cell-free systems. In this project, the role of compartmentalization on a model biosynthetic reaction will be explored systematically. Compartments will be examined to uncover how spatial segregation and the nature of the segregating compartment can enhance cell-free synthesis. The approach will couple compartmentalization with techniques in cell-free metabolism and regulation. Computational modeling will be employed to modularly implement production of a model biomolecule. The contribution of the project results will be to markedly improve biological synthesis in cell-free environments by integrating compartmentalization, controlled transport, and cell-free expression systems to achieve greater temporal control and expand the environments in which such systems can be employed.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_div_long_name: Division of Chemical, Bioengineering, Environmental, and Transport Systems

por.por_cntn:
The goal of this project was to develop a platform to control the spatial and temporal features of a biochemical reaction carried out using cellular components including cell-free extracts and cellular compartments. Our approach was to use compartments, called ‘pseudo-organelles,’ to segregate different components of the biochemical reaction and then modularly implement the organelles into a larger “pseudo-cell” chassis in order to execute the biochemical reaction.  Using both synthetic lipid vesicles and bacterial microcompartments as compartments, we uncovered emergent behaviors upon bacterial microcompartment encapsulation in synthetic lipid compartments such as the chemotaxis (or directed transport) of catalytically active microcompartments toward a substrate the microcompartment was acting upon. In addition, this project sought to uncover design rules to integrate functional membrane proteins into synthetic vesicle membranes. Together, these objectives have enabled the design of new cellular mimetic systems that can be used for biosensing and biomanufacturing applications. A final outcome of this project was the design of vesicles containing biological cargo to genetically modify protein expression in a target biological cell. Together, our results support the recapitulation of specific cellular and organelle functions outside of the cell, and provide a powerful platform to synthesize and harness synthetic and cell-derived biological compartments.

The broader impacts of this grant focused on expanding research experiences for several high school science teachers. We also worked with a Research Experience for Undergraduate Program, led by Northwester’s Center of Synthetic Biology, to provide research experiences to students who have been underrepresented in STEM disciplines. In addition, we have trained several graduate students in the design of synthetic and cell-derived vesicles. The project has resulted in broad knowledge dissemination through 12 journal publications, more than 10 conference presentations to date, and training opportunities to 2 postdoctoral researchers, 13 graduate researchers, 9 undergraduate students, and 1 technician

 


Last Modified: 01/21/2025
Modified by: Neha P Kamat
